name: Div (Daeva)

christian.overview: The Persian Div (Daeva) represents a fascinating case of religious inversion: beings worshipped as gods (deva) in Vedic tradition were demonized in Zoroastrianism. This demonization process parallels and likely influenced biblical and Christian demonology.

biblicalParallels.description: The Hebrew shedim (demons) to whom Israel sacrificed parallel the daevas as false gods demanding illicit worship. Both traditions demonize foreign deities.
Paul's statement that pagan sacrifices are offered to demons (daimonia) reflects the same conceptual framework as Zoroastrian daeva-rejection.
Demons inspiring false worship and deceiving nations parallel the daevas' role as tempters and deceivers serving Angra Mainyu.
Satan disguising himself as an angel of light parallels how daevas were originally perceived as divine before being revealed as evil.

patristicInterpretation.summary: Church Fathers were aware of Persian dualism and sometimes drew on it to articulate Christian demonology while carefully distinguishing Christian teaching from Zoroastrian frameworks.

sources.author: Augustine of Hippo
sources.interpretation: Discussed the relationship between Greek daimones and biblical demons, aware of Persian influences on Hellenistic demonology.

sources.author: Basil of Caesarea
sources.interpretation: Addressed the origin of demons as fallen angels, distinguishing Christian teaching from dualistic systems that posited eternal evil principles.

historicalConnection.persianInfluence: Jewish exposure to Persian religion during and after the Babylonian exile (586-538 BCE) likely influenced the development of Jewish angelology and demonology, particularly the more elaborate systems of the intertestamental period.
historicalConnection.linguisticLink: The Greek daimon (spirit) and Persian daeva/div share Indo-European roots with Sanskrit deva (god), illustrating how "divine beings" were variously interpreted across cultures.
historicalConnection.zoroastrianParallel: Both Zoroastrian and Christian traditions teach a cosmic conflict between good and evil spirits, though Christianity maintains God's absolute sovereignty over all created beings.

theologicalDistinction.christianVsZoroastrian: Unlike Zoroastrian dualism where Ahura Mazda and Angra Mainyu are co-eternal principles, Christianity teaches that Satan and demons are created beings who fell from grace, always subject to divine sovereignty.
theologicalDistinction.redemptionFocus: Christian theology emphasizes Christ's victory over demonic powers (Colossians 2:15), liberation for the captives, not eternal conflict.

christian.typologicalReading: The Zoroastrian hope for Frashokereti (the final restoration) when all daevas will be destroyed parallels Christian eschatology, though Christians proclaim this victory already inaugurated in Christ's resurrection.
